metadata.titleEn: 30m resolution burned area product over the Tibetan Plateau (2022)
metadata.description: The dataset is the 30m resolution burned area product of 2022 over the Tibetan Plateau. Time series Landsat land surface reflectance was employed, and sensitive parameters for burned area extraction were selected, including band (blue, green, red, NIR, SWIR1, and SWIR2) surface reflectance, and several spectral indices, i.e. NRB,NBR2, BAI,MIRBI,NDVI,GEMI,SAVI, and NDMI. Sample database of burned and unburned types was constructed, and 30m resolution burned area product was generated with the machine learning (random forest) algorithm. Overall accuracy of the burned area product is over 90%. It can provide data product support for the research and applications in fire monitoring, carbon emission studies, ecological environment monitoring, global change research and other fields.
metadata.instructions: The burned area data product uses longitude and latitude projection, with a spatial resolution of 0.00025 ° (about 30 meters), and is stored in GeoTIFF format. For the pixel value, 1 represents the burned area pixel, and the null value represents the non burned area pixel.

background: Accurate and complete data of ﬁre locations and Burned areas (BA) are important for a variety of applications including quantifying trends and patterns of ﬁre occurrence and assessing the impacts of ﬁres on a range of natural and social systems, e.g., simulating carbon emissions from biomass burning. Remotely-sensed satellite imagery has been widely used to generate burned area products. Burned area products at the global scale using satellite images have been mostly based on coarse spatial resolution data such as Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR), Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite (GOES), VEGETATION, or Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) images. The recently released Fire_cci product was produced based on MODIS images and has the highest spatial resolution (250 m) of all the existing global BA products, and it can greatly support global climate modeling at moderate resolution thanks to its promising results. However, owing to the growing availability of satellite images of higher resolution, the requirement of BA products derived from those images is also increasing as these products can provide more detailed perimeters of BA, as well as small burned patches. For instance, imagery collected by the family of Landsat sensors is useful and appropriate for monitoring the extent of BA and provides spatial and temporal resolutions ideal for science and management applications. Landsat sensors can provide a longer temporal record (from the 1970s until now) of burned area relative to existing global BA products and potentially with increased accuracy and spatial detail in most areas on the Earth. In summary, global BA products are only available at coarse spatial resolution, while 30-m resolution burned area products are limited to speciﬁc regions. One of the difﬁculties in producing Landsat-based BA products is that the traditional approaches successfully applied to extract global BA from MODIS, VEGETATION, etc., do not work well due to the limited temporal resolution of the Landsat sensors. Moreover, the analysis of post-ﬁre reﬂectance may be easily contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in Tropical regions. However, thanks to Google Earth Engine (GEE), a new generation of cloud computing platforms with access to a huge catalog of satellite imagery and global-scale analysis capabilities, it is now possible to perform global-scale geospatial analysis efﬁciently as the pre-processing of satellite images becomes more user-friendly.
research objective: In this study, however, we focus on an automated global burned area mapping approach based on Landsat images. By utilizing the huge catalog of satellite imagery, as well as the high-performance computing capacity of Google Earth Engine, we propose an automated pipeline for generating 30-m resolution global-scale annual burned area maps from time-series of Landsat images, and a novel 30-m resolution Global annual Burned Area Map of 2015 (GABAM 2015) was released.
challenges: One of the difﬁculties in producing Landsat-based BA products is that the traditional approaches successfully applied to extract global BA from MODIS, VEGETATION, etc., do not work well due to the limited temporal resolution of the Landsat sensors. Moreover, the analysis of post-ﬁre reﬂectance may be easily contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in Tropical regions.
methods: All the available Landsat-8 images during 2014–2015 and various spectral indices were utilized to calculate the burned probability of each pixel using random decision forests, which were globally trained with stratiﬁed (considering both ﬁre frequency and type of land cover) samples, and a seed-growing approach was conducted to shape the ﬁnal burned areas after several carefully-designed logical ﬁlters (NDVI ﬁlter, Normalized Burned Ratio (NBR) ﬁlter, and temporal ﬁlter). The Random Forest (RF) algorithm provided by GEE was applied to train a decision forest classiﬁer, and the global training data consisted of 6735 burned and 6146 unburned samples, which were manually collected from 120 Landsat scenes generated by stratiﬁed random sampling. For the purpose of burned area mapping, 6 bands of the Landsat-8 image were used, i.e., three visible bands (blue, 0.452–0.512 µm; green, 0.533–0.590 µm; red, 0.636–0.673 µm), Near Infrared band (NIR, 0.851–0.879 µm), and two Short Wave Infrared bands (SWIR1, 1.566–1.651µm; SWIR2, 2.107–2.294 µm).
dataset: In this study, all the available Landsat images during 2014–2015 were the main data source used for global BA mapping. The Quality Assessment (QA) band of Landsat image, which was generated by the FMaskalgorithm, was used to perform QA masking. Validation: Commonly, when satellite data are used as reference data, they should have higher spatial resolution than the data used to generate the BA product. Consequently, in this study, some publicly-available satellite images of higher-resolution were utilized, while Landsat comprised the majority of the validation data source. Speciﬁcally, Landsat-8 (LC8) images were employed to generate reference data independently for most of the validation sites except those located in the United States (U.S.), South America, and China.
findings: Cross-comparison with the recent Fire_cci Version 5.0 BA product found a similar spatial distribution and a strong correlation (R2 = 0.74) between the burned areas from the two products, although differences were found in speciﬁc land cover categories (particularly in agriculture land). Preliminary global validation showed the commission and omission errors of GABAM 2015 to be 13.17% and 30.13%, respectively.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that has been used to generate high-resolution burned area products in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: The data collection method involves using time-series Landsat satellite data to produce 30-meter resolution burned area products. This approach includes selecting sensitive spectral parameters and indices, such as NRB, NBR2, BAI, MIRBI, NDVI, GEMI, SAVI, and NDMI, to construct samples of burned and unburned areas. The method utilizes machine learning algorithms, specifically a random forest model, to develop the burned area products.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced when producing burned area products using Landsat images?
Example.Answer: A challenge encountered is that traditional approaches for extracting global burned areas, which work well with coarser resolution data like MODIS, do not perform as effectively with Landsat images due to their limited temporal resolution. Additionally, post-fire reflectance analysis can be contaminated by clouds or weakened by rapid vegetation recovery, particularly in tropical regions.

Example.Answer: For validation, higher-resolution satellite images are used as reference data, with Landsat-8 images serving as the primary data source for most validation sites. This approach ensures the burned area mapping products are accurate by comparing them against data with higher spatial resolution, thereby helping to refine and evaluate the quality of the burned area products.

Definition.Question: What is the 'random decision forests' method in the context of generating burned area maps?
Definition.Answer: The 'random decision forests' method involves calculating the burned probability of each pixel using random decision forests, which are globally trained with stratified samples considering both fire frequency and type of land cover. This method is applied to Landsat-8 images and uses a seed-growing approach to determine the final burned areas after applying logical filters like NDVI, NBR, and temporal filters.

Definition.Question: What does 'cloud computing platforms' refer to in the context of geospatial analysis for burned area mapping?
Definition.Answer: In the context of geospatial analysis for burned area mapping, 'cloud computing platforms' refer to platforms like Google Earth Engine (GEE), which provide high-performance computing capacity and access to a vast catalog of satellite imagery. These platforms enable efficient global-scale geospatial analysis and make the pre-processing of satellite images more user-friendly.

Definition.Question: What does 'Quality Assessment (QA) masking' mean in the context of satellite imagery for burned area mapping?
Definition.Answer: 'Quality Assessment (QA) masking' refers to the process of using the QA band of Landsat images, generated by the FMask algorithm, to perform quality assessment and ensure the accuracy of the data used for global burned area mapping. This process helps in validating and ensuring the reliability of the dataset by masking out clouds and other anomalies.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of Landsat satellite data for burned area mapping compare to the use of MODIS images in terms of spatial resolution and data processing techniques?
Comparison.Answer: Landsat satellite data offers higher spatial resolution (30 m) compared to MODIS images, which typically have a resolution of 250 m. While MODIS-derived burned area products are available at a global scale, Landsat-based products provide more detailed perimeters of burned areas, though they are limited to specific regions. The traditional approaches used for MODIS do not work well with Landsat due to its limited temporal resolution. However, using Google Earth Engine, an automated pipeline was developed for generating high-resolution burned area maps from Landsat images, overcoming some of these challenges.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when producing burned area products using Landsat images compared to other satellite data sources like VEGETATION or AVHRR?
Comparison.Answer: The production of burned area products using Landsat images faces challenges such as limited temporal resolution, which is not as significant for other sources like VEGETATION or AVHRR with coarser resolutions. Additionally, post-fire reflectance analysis in Landsat images can be contaminated by clouds or quick vegetation recovery, particularly in tropical regions. These issues are less problematic with coarser resolution sensors. Despite these challenges, Landsat provides more detailed spatial information, which is valuable for specific regional analyses.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the methods for creating burned area maps using Landsat-8 images differ from those using higher-resolution satellite data for validation purposes?
Comparison.Answer: The method of creating burned area maps using Landsat-8 images involves calculating burned probability using random decision forests and applying logical filters to shape the final burned areas. In contrast, validation often involves using higher-resolution satellite images that provide finer spatial detail than Landsat, ensuring that the reference data for validation are more precise. Landsat-8 data serves as the main source for mapping, while higher-resolution images are utilized to independently validate these maps at select sites.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when using satellite imagery for creating detailed burned area datasets, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using satellite imagery for creating detailed burned area datasets include the limited temporal resolution of certain sensors like Landsat, which can hinder the extraction of global burned areas. Moreover, post-fire reflectance analysis can be contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in tropical regions. These challenges can be addressed by utilizing platforms like Google Earth Engine, which offers high-performance computing capacity and a vast catalog of satellite imagery, enabling more efficient global-scale geospatial analysis.

Interpretation.Question: How can machine learning algorithms enhance the accuracy of burned area mapping from satellite data?
Interpretation.Answer: Machine learning algorithms, such as Random Forests, can enhance the accuracy of burned area mapping by analyzing various spectral indices from satellite data to calculate the burned probability of each pixel. By using a globally trained decision forest classifier with stratified samples, and employing a seed-growing approach with logical filters like NDVI and NBR, these algorithms can produce more precise delineations of burned areas.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using higher-resolution satellite imagery for burned area products compared to coarse-resolution data?
Interpretation.Answer: Using higher-resolution satellite imagery for burned area products allows for more detailed mapping of the perimeters and smaller burned patches. This can provide increased spatial detail and potentially greater accuracy, overcoming the limitations of coarse-resolution data that may not capture finer details. Higher resolution imagery, like that from Landsat sensors, offers a longer temporal record and is particularly useful for science and management applications, although it requires sophisticated processing to address issues like cloud contamination and rapid vegetation recovery.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the availability of higher-resolution satellite imagery increasing the demand for more detailed burned area products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The growing availability of higher-resolution satellite imagery is increasing the demand for more detailed burned area products because these products can provide more detailed perimeters of burned areas, as well as small burned patches, which are not visible in coarser resolution data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a machine learning algorithm, such as the random forest model, for developing high-resolution burned area products in terms of data accuracy and application scope?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a machine learning algorithm like the random forest model can result in burned area products with a high overall accuracy of over 90%, which supports applications in fire monitoring, carbon emission research, and ecological studies. It allows for the creation of detailed spatial maps, enhancing the understanding of fire impacts on various ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the utilization of cloud computing platforms like Google Earth Engine influence the outcomes of global-scale geospatial analysis for burned area mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of cloud computing platforms such as Google Earth Engine facilitates efficient global-scale geospatial analysis by providing access to a vast catalog of satellite imagery and high-performance computing capabilities. This approach streamlines the pre-processing of images, allowing for the automated generation of detailed 30-meter resolution global burned area maps, such as the Global annual Burned Area Map of 2015.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of applying spectral indices and Landsat data in the production of burned area products on the resolution and reliability of these datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying spectral indices and Landsat data in burned area product development improves the resolution to 30 meters, allowing for more detailed mapping of burned perimeters and detection of smaller burned patches. This approach enhances the accuracy and reliability of the datasets, although challenges such as cloud contamination and rapid vegetation recovery need to be addressed, particularly in tropical regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in constructing a sample library for distinguishing burned and non-burned areas using spectral indices from satellite imagery?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To construct a sample library for distinguishing burned and non-burned areas, one must utilize time-series Landsat satellite data and select fire-sensitive spectral parameters, including surface reflectance from various bands (blue, green, red, near-infrared, shortwave infrared 1, and shortwave infrared 2) as well as spectral indices like NRB, NBR2, BAI, MIRBI, NDVI, GEMI, SAVI, and NDMI. These parameters are used to build a library of samples for burned and non-burned areas, which are then processed using machine learning algorithms, specifically the random forest model, to develop and produce burned area products at 30-meter resolution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to address the challenges of limited temporal resolution and cloud contamination in Landsat-based burned area mapping?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address the challenges of limited temporal resolution and cloud contamination in Landsat-based burned area mapping, the methodology involves using all available Landsat-8 images over a specified period and applying spectral indices to calculate the burned probability of each pixel. A random decision forest classification is trained with stratified samples, using a seed-growing approach to delineate the final burned areas. Logical filters, such as NDVI, Normalized Burned Ratio (NBR), and temporal filters, are applied to refine the results. The use of Google Earth Engine facilitates global-scale geospatial analysis and pre-processing of satellite images by offering high-performance computing capabilities.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can Landsat images be utilized to validate burned area products and enhance their accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Landsat images can be utilized to validate burned area products by using them as a primary data source for generating reference data independently for most validation sites. These images, particularly from Landsat-8, provide higher spatial resolution, which is crucial when satellite data are used as reference data. For validation, publicly-available satellite images with higher resolution are employed alongside Landsat, ensuring comprehensive validation across different regions. This method enhances the accuracy of burned area products by cross-comparing with existing products like Fire_cci and identifying discrepancies in specific land cover categories.

Enablement.Question: What methods or technologies enable the creation of high-resolution burned area products from satellite imagery?
Enablement.Answer: The use of Landsat satellite imagery, combined with machine learning algorithms such as random forest, enables the creation of high-resolution burned area products. Specifically, time-series Landsat data are utilized along with spectral indices to construct samples and produce 30-meter resolution burned area products.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be addressed to enhance the accuracy of burned area products derived from Landsat images?
Enablement.Answer: One challenge is the limited temporal resolution of Landsat sensors, which affects the extraction of burned areas. Additionally, cloud contamination and rapid vegetation recovery can impact post-fire reflectance analysis. Overcoming these challenges involves careful sample training and the use of additional logical filters such as NDVI and NBR filters.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional approaches for extracting global burned areas not work well when applied to higher resolution datasets like Landsat?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional approaches may face challenges due to the limited temporal resolution of Landsat sensors, which affects the analysis of post-fire reflectance. This analysis can be easily contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in regions with a tropical climate.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in generating high-resolution burned area datasets using satellite imagery?
Expectation.Answer: One expected challenge is the need for detailed perimeters of burned areas and the identification of small burned patches, which require high-resolution imagery. The availability of such high-resolution satellite images is increasing, but traditional data processing methods may not be sufficient to handle this data effectively.

Expectation.Question: Why is the validation process crucial when using satellite data to generate burned area products, and what are the expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: The validation process ensures the accuracy of burned area products by comparing them with higher spatial resolution reference data. The expected outcome is to achieve a strong correlation with existing products and to minimize commission and omission errors, as seen in the cross-comparison with Fire_cci and preliminary global validation results.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential advantages or drawbacks of utilizing platforms like Google Earth Engine for global-scale geospatial analysis of burned areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Utilizing platforms like Google Earth Engine offers significant advantages for global-scale geospatial analysis of burned areas, including access to a vast catalog of satellite imagery, high-performance computing capabilities, and user-friendly pre-processing tools. However, potential drawbacks may include dependency on platform availability, data privacy concerns, and the need for users to have technical expertise in cloud-based geospatial analysis.

Assertion.Answer: The dataset achieves over 90% accuracy by utilizing a machine learning approach with a random forest model, which is trained using a comprehensive sample library of burned and unburned areas. This process involves selecting sensitive spectral parameters from Landsat satellite data to accurately identify burned areas.

Assertion.Question: I can't grasp how higher resolution satellite imagery enhances the identification of smaller burned patches compared to global products.
Assertion.Answer: Higher resolution satellite imagery, like that from Landsat, captures more spatial detail, which is crucial for identifying smaller burned patches. This detailed imagery, combined with various spectral indices and machine learning techniques, allows for more precise mapping of burned areas than coarser global products.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure why traditional methods struggle with temporal resolution when using Landsat data for global burned area mapping.
Assertion.Answer: Traditional methods face challenges with Landsat's limited temporal resolution because these methods were developed for sensors with more frequent data capture, like MODIS. Landsat's longer revisit time can result in data gaps, which complicates the production of consistent burned area maps. However, platforms like Google Earth Engine can mitigate these issues by providing access to extensive image archives and processing capabilities.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a data collection method that utilizes a time-series of satellite imagery for mapping burned areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: A data collection method involves using time-series Landsat satellite data to map burned areas. This method selects sensitive spectral parameters, including surface reflectance of various bands (blue, green, red, near-infrared, shortwave infrared 1, and shortwave infrared 2) and spectral indices like NRB, NBR2, BAI, MIRBI, NDVI, GEMI, SAVI, and NDMI. Machine learning algorithms, specifically the Random Forest model, are employed to classify and produce 30-m resolution burned area products.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and explain a challenge associated with producing high-resolution burned area products from satellite imagery.
Request/Directive.Answer: A challenge in producing high-resolution burned area products from satellite imagery is the limited temporal resolution of Landsat sensors, which can affect traditional approaches used for extracting global burned areas. The post-fire reflectance analysis may be contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, especially in tropical regions. These factors complicate the accurate mapping of burned areas using higher-resolution data from Landsat.

Request/Directive.Question: Please recommend a potential dataset that could be used for validating burned area products derived from satellite images.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential dataset for validating burned area products derived from satellite images could be publicly available satellite images with higher spatial resolution than the data used to generate the burned area product. For instance, Landsat-8 images were used in some studies to generate reference data for validation sites, except in specific regions like the United States, South America, and China.
